The 'Brazilian Armed Forces' (, ) is the unified military organization
comprising the Brazilian Army (including the Brazilian Army Aviation), the
Brazilian Navy (including the Brazilian Marine Corps and Brazilian Naval
Aviation) and the Brazilian Air Force. According to article 144 of the 1988
Brazilian Constitution, the para-military Military Police alongside the
Military Firefighters Corps are constitutionally considered an auxiliary and
potential reserve to the Army, though subordinate to the state governors. They
can, however, be compelled to federal service under a statute similar to posse
comitatus[https://www.planalto.gov.br/ccivil_03/Constituicao/Constitui%C3%A7ao-
.htm].

Brazil's armed forces are the largest in Latin America, with 327,710 active-duty
troops and officers. With no serious external or internal threats, the armed
forces are searching for a new role. They are expanding their presence in the
Amazon under the Northern Corridor (Calha Norte) program. In 1994 Brazilian
troops joined United Nations (UN) peacekeeping forces in five countries.
Brazilian soldiers have been in Haiti since 2004 leading the United Nations
Stabilization Mission (MINUSTAH). [http://www.agenciabrasil.gov.br/news-in-
english/2010/01/14/materia.2010-01-14.1625659789/view Brazilian troops in
Haiti]

The Brazilian military, especially the army, has become more involved in civic-
action programs, education, health care, and constructing roads, bridges, and
railroads across the nation. Although the 1988 constitution preserves the
external and internal roles of the armed forces, it places the military under
presidential authority. Thus, the new charter changed the manner in which the
military could exercise its moderating
power. [http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/brazil/intro.htm
Information - Brazilian Army]
